definitions.definition: to run, drive, etc. after somebody/something in order to catch them or it

examples.text: The kids **chased each other** around the kitchen table.
We were chased by a bull while crossing the field.
He chased after the burglar but couldn't catch him.
The boys were chasing each other around the yard.
They chased after the burglar but didn't catch him.

definitions.definition: to force somebody/something to run away

examples.text: Chase the cat out—we don't want her in the kitchen.
This particular fish chases off any other fish that enters its territory.

definitions.definition: to try to obtain or achieve something, for example money, work or success

examples.text: Too many people are chasing too few jobs nowadays.
The team is chasing its first win in five games.

definitions.definition: to try to persuade somebody to have a sexual relationship with you

examples.text: Kevin's been chasing after Joan for months.

definitions.definition: to persuade somebody to do something that they should have done already

examples.text: I need to chase him about organizing the meeting.
I've been **chasing around** town all morning looking for a present for Sharon.

definitions.definition: to cut patterns or designs on metal
to be very busy but in fact achieve very little

wordOrigin: verb senses 1 to 5 Middle English: from Old French chacier (verb), chace (noun), based on Latin captare ‘continue to take’, from capere ‘take’. verb sense 6 late Middle English: apparently from earlier enchase, from Old French enchasser.
